title: A Python Execution Timer with Decorator
content:
Ref: https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/timing-functions-with-decorators-python/

timeit.py123456789101112131415161718192021from time import time  def timer(func):    # This function shows the execution time of     # the function object passed    def wrap_func(*args, **kwargs):        t1 = time()        result = func(*args, **kwargs)        t2 = time()        print(f'Function {func.__name__!r} executed in {(t2-t1):.4f}s')        return result    return wrap_func    @timerdef long_time(n):    for i in range(n):        for j in range(100000):            i*j  long_time(5)

title: RIPv2 & RIPng Introduction
content:
Routing Information Protocol


Version 1
Version 2
Next Generation




RFC 1058
RFC 4822
RFC 2080



RIPv2

Interior Gateway Protocol (IGP) subset
Protocol & Port: UDP, 520
Distance Vector (Bellman-Ford) algorithm
Classless Routing Protocol, support CIDR (Classless Inter-Domain Routing，無類域間路由)
Metric: Hop count, max up to 15 of each single route, value 16 as unreachable / inifinite

Packet Frame
Timer / Intervals
All mentioned as default:

Update Timer: 30 secs
Invalid Timer: 180 secs
Hold-Down Timer: 180 secs
Flush Timer: 240 secs


Authentication


Simple Password
With authentication key of up to 16 characters included in the packet, if password doesnt match, then discard the packet.
This method provides very little security level, which is posiible to learn the key through by sniffer RIP packets.


MD5 algorithm
By using MD5 method to create a crypto checksum of a RIP packet and an authentication key with up to 16 characters.
The transmitted packet doesn’t contain the authentication key itself but a crypto checksum, called the digest


Ref: https://sc1.checkpoint.com/documents/R81/WebAdminGuides/EN/CP_R81_Gaia_Advanced_Routing_AdminGuide/Topics-GARG/RIP-v2.htm
RIPng

Supports multiple IPv6 addresses on each interface
Protocol & Port: UDP, 521

Packet Frame

Source: https://support.huawei.com/enterprise/en/doc/EDOC1100058403/b0f8860e/ripng-packet-format
the version field: set to 1
the command field:
1-Request: A request to send all or part of of routing table. (specific / whole-table )
2-Response: A response containing all or part of routing table, this can be sent in response to a request or sent in unsolicited.
The maximum RTE(s) capbility of a packet: (depends on MTU size of the interface
123               +   MTU - sizeof(IPv6_Headers) - UDP_Header_Len - RIPng_Header_Len   +#RTE(s) =  INT | -----------------------------------------------------------------  |               +                           RTE_size                                 +
Source: https://sites.google.com/site/amitsciscozone/ipv6/ripng
Route Table Entry Packet Detail
1. Next Hop RTE / Request packet
It defines the IPv6 address of the next hop and is located before a group of IPv6-prefix RTEs that have the same next hop. The Metric field of a next hop RTE is always 0xFF.

Source: https://support.huawei.com/enterprise/en/doc/EDOC1100058403/b0f8860e/ripng-packet-format

2. IPv6 Prefix RTE / Response packet
It describes the destination IPv6 address and the cost in the RIPng routing table and is located after a next hop RTE. A next hop RTE can be followed by multiple different IPv6-prefix RTEs

Source: https://support.huawei.com/enterprise/en/doc/EDOC1100058403/b0f8860e/ripng-packet-format

Timer / Intervals
All mentioned as default:

Update Timer: 30 secs
(Route) Timeout  / Age Timer: 180 secs
Garbage Collection Timeout Timer: 120 secs
Hold-Down Timer: (NOT described in RFC 2080)

mentioned in https://support.huawei.com/enterprise/en/doc/EDOC1100058403/c193f046/timers

disable by default, if configured, hold-down timer starts after receives a route with cost greater than 16.





Update Timer has a random offset within +/- 0 to 15 seconds,
the offset is derived from 0.5 * Update Timer
Input Processing
Request Messages

normally sent as multicasts, can be unicast direct


Ref:

wiki: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Routing_Information_Protocol

title: A step by step how to start docker-compose container at boot
content:
Post in Medium: https://jason19970210.medium.com/a-step-by-step-how-to-start-docker-compose-container-at-boot-effe9964e57f
Once create a docker container, we might hope the container can start automatically by itself, at the boot and even reboot.

Here we will go through with docker-compose yaml config file, ex. docker-compose.yml .
As the basic yaml file:
docker-compose.yml12345678version: "3"service:    restart: always # the most important line for this post    image: xxxx #docker image    environment:        - key : value ...    ports:        - 8080:80
Let’s take a look at docker restart policy with 4 types :
Ref : https://docs.docker.com/config/containers/start-containers-automatically/#use-a-restart-policy
no : Do not automatically restart the container.  (the default)
on-failure[:max-retries] : Restart the container if it exits due to an error, which manifests as a non-zero exit code. Optionally, limit the number of times the Docker daemon attempts to restart the container using the :max-retries option.
always : Always restart the container if it stops. If it is manually stopped, it is restarted only when Docker daemon restarts or the container itself is manually restarted. (See the second bullet listed in restart policy details)
unless-stopped : Similar to always, except that when the container is stopped (manually or otherwise), it is not restarted even after Docker daemon restarts.
With the basic docker command start a container:
$ docker run -d --restart <restart_policy> <docker_image>
Please make sure the docker daemon has been enable to launch at boot:
12345$ sudo systemctl start docker$ sudo systemctl enable docker$ sudo systemctl is-enabled docker ## the output should be enabled
Check the docker container restart policy
$ docker inspect <container_id> | fgrep -i restart -A 5
if nothing is set to restart:
123456"AppArmorProfile": "docker-default","RestartPolicy": {    "Name": "",    "MaximumRetryCount":0},...
Once we set the restart parameter:
123456"AppArmorProfile": "docker-default","RestartPolicy": {    "Name": "always",    "MaximumRetryCount":0},...
Now the container can restart by itself after the pc/server reboot.
Hope this can help you and save a day off !!
Ref: https://stackoverflow.com/a/70991572

title: Raspberry Pi 4 with Multiple UART Interfaces
content:
Sometimes we need the lots of components, sensors, modules using the UART interfaces to communicate with the Raspberry Pi.

Post in Medium: https://medium.com/@jason19970210/raspberry-pi-4-with-multiple-uart-interface-4eac75f74d7c
Environment

Hardware : Raspberry Pi 4 Model B (BCM2177*) ref
Operation System : Respbian Linux 11
CPU Arch: armv7l

There are 2 types of UART interface existed on Raspberry Pi, mini UART & PL011 UART.
By default, /dev/ttyS0 maps to mini UART; on the other hand, /dev/ttyAMA0 maps to PL011 UART.
Software Setup
12$ sudo su$ vim /boot/config.txt
add following lines at the end of the file:
12345678# enable serial interfaceenable_uart=1dtoverlay=uart0dtoverlay=uart1dtoverlay=uart2dtoverlay=uart3dtoverlay=uart4dtoverlay=uart5
Save, exit & Reboot !!
Check system open the serial by command $ ls -al /dev/ttyAMA*
123456$ ls -al /dev/ttyAMA*crw-rw---- 1 root dialout 204, 64 Dec 16 16:01 /dev/ttyAMA0crw-rw---- 1 root dialout 204, 65 Dec 16 16:01 /dev/ttyAMA1crw-rw---- 1 root dialout 204, 66 Dec 16 16:01 /dev/ttyAMA2crw-rw---- 1 root dialout 204, 67 Dec 16 16:01 /dev/ttyAMA3crw-rw---- 1 root dialout 204, 68 Dec 16 16:01 /dev/ttyAMA4
Let’s take a look into the Raspberry Pi 4 Model B GPIO Pinout:

GPIO Pinout : https://www.raspberrypi.com/documentation/computers/os.html#gpio-and-the-40-pin-header
Hardware Setup
Raspberry Pi Pin pair with UART:
123456           TXD       RXD         Communication Portuart0 :  GPIO 14    GPIO 15         /dev/ttyAMA0 uart1 :  GPIO 0     GPIO 1          /dev/ttyAMA1uart2 :  GPIO 4     GPIO 5          /dev/ttyAMA2uart3 :  GPIO 8     GPIO 9          /dev/ttyAMA3uart4 :  GPIO 12    GPIO 13         /dev/ttyAMA4
PC setup with USB-to-UART Adapter :

FT232 : https://www.waveshare.com/ft232-usb-uart-board-type-a.htm
Please make sure GND is connected correctly !
USB-to-UART TXD connect to Raspberry Pi uart RXD GPIO Pin
USB-to-UART RXD connect to Raspberry Pi uart TXD GPIO Pin
Take uart3 for example:
123USB-to-UART TXD <--> GPIO 8USB-to-UART RXD <--> GPIO 9USB-to-UART GND <--> GND
Implementation
Once finish setup, open a serial console on PC (ex. Putty) with correct COM Port (ex. COM3) & Baud Rate set to 115200
Then open a terminal in Raspberry Pi, send message from CLI to PC :
$ echo 'hello' > /dev/ttyAMA3
This command should send the string hello to PC via /dev/ttyAMA3 , then the string will be parsed by PC, finally display on serial console.
Hope this article can help those makers connect more devices via multiple UART interfaces !!
